title: Intermediate SSM Analysis
text: ’ve already seen adding measures argument can change ssm_analyze() analyzing means analyzing correlations. Similarly, can change analyzing observations single group analyzing subgroups separately. done using grouping argument. argument needs contain single variable (name column number) specifies observation’s group. instance, Gender variable jz2017 dataset factor two levels: Female Male. analyze gender separately, need add grouping = Gender argument function call. Note output summary() looks previous mean-based analyses except now two Profile blocks: one Female one Male. similar modification occur generate table figure. Mean-based Structural Summary Statistics 95% CIs  number groups can analyzed way, output contain additional profile blocks, table contain additional rows, figure contain additional points. grouping variable just needs contain one level (.e., unique value). Also notice , plot , Male profile dashed border instead typical solid border. Male profile low prototypicality (.e., \(R^2<.70\)) therefore plot untrustworthy. also possible prevent profiles low prototypicality plotting using lowfit argument.
code: data("jz2017") data("iipsc") jz2017s <- standardize(jz2017, PA:NO, octants(), instrument = iipsc, sample = 1) results <- ssm_analyze(jz2017s, PA:NO, octants(), grouping = Gender) summary(results) #> Call: #> ssm_analyze(.data = jz2017s, scales = PA:NO, angles = octants(),  #>     grouping = Gender) #>  #> Statistical Basis:    Mean Scores  #> Bootstrap Resamples:  2000  #> Confidence Level:     0.95  #> Listwise Deletion:    TRUE  #> Scale Displacements:  90 135 180 225 270 315 360 45  #>  #> Profile [Female]: #>                Estimate   Lower CI   Upper CI #> Elevation         0.946      0.907      0.984 #> X-Value           0.459      0.422      0.498 #> Y-Value          -0.310     -0.357     -0.266 #> Amplitude         0.554      0.511      0.600 #> Displacement    325.963    321.834    329.805 #> Model Fit         0.889                       #>  #> Profile [Male]: #>                Estimate   Lower CI   Upper CI #> Elevation         0.884      0.839      0.928 #> X-Value           0.227      0.191      0.262 #> Y-Value          -0.186     -0.225     -0.147 #> Amplitude         0.294      0.256      0.330 #> Displacement    320.685    313.386    327.985 #> Model Fit         0.824 ssm_table(results) ssm_plot(results) ssm_plot(results, lowfit = FALSE)

title: Intermediate SSM Analysis
text: final argument master contrast, allows us compare two groups measures. value argument must one following strings: “none” contrast (default), “model” model contrast, “test” parameter contrast. model contrast can useful mean-based analyses first generates scores group (measure), calculates difference scores, finally estimates SSM parameters difference scores. parameter contrast typically desired inferential comparison first generates scores group (measure), estimates SSM parameters scores, finally calculates difference parameters. keep code simpler discourage “fishing expeditions,” two groups measures can compared time.

title: Intermediate SSM Analysis
text: compare mean profiles females males, can start syntax add contrast argument. sake illustration, use model contrast , purposes, parameter contrast might appropriate. Note profile blocks used replaced contrast block. default, contrast made subtracting first level grouping variable second level (e.g., Male - Female). provides indication direction contrast. can generate table figure display results. Note , used model contrast, figure circular figure contrast figure see . However, get contrast figure used parameter contrast. Mean-based Structural Summary Statistic Contrasts 95% CIs
code: results4 <- ssm_analyze(jz2017s, PA:NO, octants(), grouping = Gender, contrast = "model") summary(results4) #> Call: #> ssm_analyze(.data = jz2017s, scales = PA:NO, angles = octants(),  #>     grouping = Gender, contrast = "model") #>  #> Statistical Basis:    Mean Scores  #> Bootstrap Resamples:  2000  #> Confidence Level:     0.95  #> Listwise Deletion:    TRUE  #> Scale Displacements:  90 135 180 225 270 315 360 45  #>  #> Contrast [Male - Female]: #>                Estimate   Lower CI   Upper CI #> Elevation        -0.062     -0.119     -0.004 #> X-Value          -0.232     -0.285     -0.181 #> Y-Value           0.124      0.066      0.183 #> Amplitude         0.263      0.209      0.321 #> Displacement    151.858    141.234    164.387 #> Model Fit         0.855 ssm_table(results4) ssm_plot(results4)

what: Contrasts between measures in a group
title: Intermediate SSM Analysis

title: Introduction to SSM Analysis
text: Circumplex models popular within many areas psychology offer parsimonious account complex psychological domains, emotion interpersonal functioning. parsimony achieved understanding phenomena domain “blend” two primary dimensions. instance, circumplex models emotion typically represent affective phenomena blend valence (pleasantness versus unpleasantness) arousal (activity versus passivity), whereas circumplex models interpersonal functioning typically represent interpersonal phenomena blend communion (affiliation versus separation) agency (dominance versus submissiveness). models often depicted circles around intersection two dimensions (see figure). given phenomenon can located within circular space reference two underlying dimensions (e.g., anger blend unpleasantness activity). Circumplex scales contain multiple subscales attempt measure different blends two primary dimensions (.e., different parts circle). Although historically circumplex scales many sixteen subscales, become common use eight subscales: one “pole” two primary dimensions one “quadrant” combines two dimensions. order set subscales considered circumplex, must exhibit certain properties. Circumplex fit analyses can used quantify properties. Circumplex data composed scores set circumplex scales one participants (e.g., persons organizations). data usually collected via self-report, informant-report, observational ratings order locate psychological phenomena within circular space circumplex model. example, therapist might want understand interpersonal problems encountered individual patient, social psychologist might want understand emotional experiences group participants experiment, personality psychologist might want understand kind interpersonal behaviors associated trait (e.g., extraversion).

title: Introduction to SSM Analysis
text: SSM estimates cosine curve data using following equation: \[S_i = e + \times \cos(\theta_i - d)\] \(S_i\) \(\theta_i\) score angle scale \(\), respectively, \(e\), \(\), \(d\) elevation, amplitude, displacement parameters, respectively. discuss parameters, however, can also estimate fit SSM model. essentially close cosine curve observed data points. Deviations (red, ) lower model fit.  fit less 0.70, considered “unacceptable” elevation parameter interpreted. fit 0.70 0.80, considered “adequate,” greater 0.80, considered “good.” Sometimes SSM model fit called prototypicality denoted using \(R^2\). first SSM parameter elevation \(e\), calculated mean scores. size general factor circumplex model interpretation varies scale scale. measures interpersonal problems, interpreted generalized interpersonal distress. using correlation-based SSM, \(|e|\ge.15\) considered “marked” \(|e|<.15\) considered “modest.”  second SSM parameter amplitude \(\), calculated difference highest point curve curve’s mean. interpreted distinctiveness differentiation profile: much peaked versus flat. Similar elevation, using correlation-based SSM, \(\ge.15\) considered “marked” \(<.15\) considered “modest.”  final SSM parameter displacement \(d\), calculated angle curve reaches highest point. interpreted style profile. instance, \(d=90^\circ\) using circumplex scale defines 90 degrees “domineering,” profile’s style domineering.  interpreting three parameters, can understand profile much parsimoniously trying interpret eight subscales individually. approach also leverages circumplex relationship (.e., dependency) among subscales. also possible transform amplitude displacement parameters estimates distance x-axis y-axis, shown output discussed .

title: Introduction to SSM Analysis
text: illustrate SSM functions, use example dataset jz2017, provided Zimmermann & Wright (2017) reformatted package. dataset includes self-report data 1166 undergraduate students. Students completed circumplex measure interpersonal problems eight subscales (PA, BC, DE, FG, HI, JK, LM, ) measure personality disorder symptoms ten subscales (PARPD, SCZPD, SZTPD, ASPD, BORPD, HISPD, NARPD, AVPD, DPNPD, OCPD). information variables can accessed using ?jz2017 command R. circumplex scales jz2017 come Inventory Interpersonal Problems - Short Circumplex (IIP-SC). scales can arranged following circular model, organized around two primary dimensions agency (y-axis) communion (x-axis). Note two-letter scale abbreviations angular values based convention. high score PA indicates one interpersonal problems related “domineering” high agency, whereas high score DE indicates problems related “cold” low communion. Scales directly y-axis x-axis (.e., BC, FG, JK, ) represent blends agency communion.

code: instrument("igicr") summary(igicr) #> IGI-CR: Interpersonal Goals Inventory for Children, Revised Version #> 32 items, 8 scales, 3 normative data sets #> Trucco, Wright, & Colder (2013) #> <https://doi.org/10.1177/1073191111411672> #>  #> The IGI-CR contains 8 circumplex scales. #> PA: +A (90 degrees) #> BC: +A-C (135 degrees) #> DE: -C (180 degrees) #> FG: -A-C (225 degrees) #> HI: -A (270 degrees) #> JK: -A+C (315 degrees) #> LM: +C (360 degrees) #> NO: +A+C (45 degrees) #>  #> The IGI-CR is rated using the following 5-point scale. #> 0. Not at all important to me #> 1. Somewhat important to me #> 2. Important to me #> 3. Very important to me #> 4. Extremely important to me #>  #> The IGI-CR contains 32 items (open-access): #> 1. Your peers respect and admire you #> 2. Your peers agree to do what you suggest #> 3. You do not show your feelings in front of your peers #> 4. You do not do anything ridiculous #> 5. Your peers do not get angry with you #> 6. Everyone feels good #> 7. You feel close to your peers #> 8. You say exactly what you want #> 9. You appear self-confident and make an impression on your peers #> 10. You get to decide what to play #> 11. You do not give away too much about yourself #> 12. You do not say stupid things when your peers are listening #> 13. You do not make your peers angry #> 14. You can put your peers in a good mood #> 15. Real friendship develops between you #> 16. Your peers listen to your opinion #> 17. Your peers think you are smart #> 18. The group does what you say #> 19. You keep your thoughts to yourself #> 20. Your peers do not laugh or make fun of you #> 21. You do not annoy your peers #> 22. You are able to please your peers #> 23. Your peers help you when you have a problem #> 24. You can state your opinion #> 25. You don't back down when there is a disagreement #> 26. You feel you have control over your peers #> 27. You do not let your peers get too close to you #> 28. You do not make a fool of yourself in front of your peers #> 29. You let your peers make decisions #> 30. You agree with your peers about things #> 31. Your peers come to you when they have a problem #> 32. You are able to tell your peers how you feel #>  #> The IGI-CR currently has 3 normative data set(s): #> 1. 387 American community adolescents (age 11-13), overall #> Trucco, Wright, & Colder (2013) #> <https://doi.org/10.1177/1073191111411672> #> 2. 174 American community adolescents (age 11-13), males #> Trucco, Wright, & Colder (2013) #> <https://doi.org/10.1177/1073191111411672> #> 3. 213 American community adolescents (age 11-13), females #> Trucco, Wright, & Colder (2013) #> <https://doi.org/10.1177/1073191111411672> scales(igicr, items = TRUE) #> The IGI-CR contains 8 circumplex scales. #> PA: +A (90 degrees) #>     1. Your peers respect and admire you #>     9. You appear self-confident and make an impression on your peers #>     17. Your peers think you are smart #>     25. You don't back down when there is a disagreement #> BC: +A-C (135 degrees) #>     2. Your peers agree to do what you suggest #>     10. You get to decide what to play #>     18. You do not do anything ridiculous #>     12. You do not say stupid things when your peers are listening #>     20. Your peers do not laugh or make fun of you #>     28. You do not make a fool of yourself in front of your peers #> HI: -A (270 degrees) #>     5. Your peers do not get angry with you #>     13. You do not make your peers angry #>     21. You do not annoy your peers #>     29. You let your peers make decisions #> JK: -A+C (315 degrees) #>     6. Everyone feels good #>     14. You can put your peers in a good mood #>     22. You are able to please your peers #>     30. You agree with your peers about things #> LM: +C (360 degrees) #>     7. You feel close to your peers #>     15. what: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze
title: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze
text: Calculate SSM parameters bootstrapped confidence intervals variety different analysis types. Depending arguments supplied, either mean-based correlation-based analyses performed, one groups used stratify data, contrasts groups measures calculated.

title: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze
code: ssm_analyze(   .data,   scales,   angles = octants(),   measures = NULL,   grouping = NULL,   contrast = c("none", "test", "model"),   boots = 2000,   interval = 0.95,   listwise = TRUE,   measures_labels = NULL )

title: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze
text: .data Required. data frame containing least circumplex scales. scales Required. variable names column numbers variables .data contain circumplex scales analyzed. angles Optional. numeric vector containing angular displacement circumplex scale included scales (degrees). (default = octants()). measures Optional. variable names column numbers one variables .data correlated circumplex scales analyzed using correlation-based SSM analyses. analyze circumplex scales using mean-based analyses, simply omit argument set NULL (default = NULL). grouping Optional. variable name column number variable .data indicates group membership observation. analyze observations single group, simply omit argument set NULL (default = NULL). contrast Optional. string indicating type contrast run. Current options "none" contrast, "model" find SSM parameters difference scores, "test" find difference SSM parameters. Note two groups measures can contrasted time (default = "none"). boots Optional. single positive integer indicating many bootstrap resamples use estimating confidence intervals (default = 2000). interval Optional. single positive number 0 1 (exclusive) indicates confidence level use estimating confidence intervals (default = 0.95). listwise Optional. logical indicating whether missing values handled listwise deletion (TRUE) pairwise deletion (FALSE). Note pairwise deletion may result different missing data patterns bootstrap resample slower compute (default = TRUE). measures_labels Optional. character vector providing label measure provided measures (order) appear results well tables plots derived results. omitted set NULL default using measures variable names (default = NULL).

title: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze
text: list containing results description analysis. results tibble SSM parameter estimates details list number bootstrap resamples (boots), confidence interval percentage level (interval), angular displacement scales (angles) call language object containing function call created object scores tibble containing mean scale scores type string indicating type SSM analysis done

title: Perform analyses using the Structural Summary Method — ssm_analyze

what: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
title: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
text: Calculate SSM parameters (without confidence intervals) set scores generate tibble customizable labels parameter value. function requires input numeric vector (coercable one) returns parameters. See ssm_score() similar function calculates SSM parameters row data frame.

title: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
code: ssm_parameters(   scores,   angles,   prefix = "",   suffix = "",   e_label = "Elev",   x_label = "Xval",   y_label = "Yval",   a_label = "Ampl",   d_label = "Disp",   f_label = "Fit" )

title: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
text: scores Required. numeric vector (single row data frame) containing one score set circumplex scales. angles Required. numeric vector containing angular displacement circumplex scale included scores (degrees). prefix Optional. string append beginning SSM parameters' variable names (default = ""). suffix Optional. string append end SSM parameters' variable names (default = ""). e_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM elevation parameter (default = "Elev"). x_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM x-value parameter (default = "Xval"). y_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM y-value parameter (default = "Yval"). a_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM amplitude parameter (default = "Ampl"). d_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM displacement parameter (default = "Disp"). f_label Optional. string representing variable name SSM fit R-squared value (default = "Fit").

title: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
text: tibble containing SSM parameters calculated scores.

title: Calculate Structural Summary Method parameters for a set of scores — ssm_parameters
code: # Manually enter octant scores scores <- c(0.55, 0.58, 0.62, 0.76, 1.21, 1.21, 1.48, 0.90) ssm_parameters(scores, angles = octants()) #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>    Elev  Xval   Yval  Ampl  Disp   Fit #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 0.914 0.351 -0.252 0.432  324. 0.878  # Customize several of the labels ssm_parameters(scores, angles = octants(), x_label = "LOV", y_label = "DOM") #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>    Elev   LOV    DOM  Ampl  Disp   Fit #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 0.914 0.351 -0.252 0.432  324. 0.878  # Add a prefix to all labels ssm_parameters(scores, angles = octants(), prefix = "IIP_") #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   IIP_Elev IIP_Xval IIP_Yval IIP_Ampl IIP_Disp IIP_Fit #>      <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1    0.914    0.351   -0.252    0.432     324.   0.878

what: Create a Circular Plot of SSM Results — ssm_plot_circle
title: Create a Circular Plot of SSM Results — ssm_plot_circle
text: Take results Structural Summary Method analysis plot point interval estimate row (e.g., group measure) circular space quantified displacement amplitude.

title: Create a Circular Plot of SSM Results — ssm_plot_circle
code: ssm_plot_circle(   .ssm_object,   amax = NULL,   legend_font_size = 12,   scale_font_size = 12,   lowfit = TRUE,   repel = FALSE,   angle_labels = NULL,   legend.box.spacing = 0,   palette = "Set2",   ... )

title: Create a Circular Plot of SSM Results — ssm_plot_circle
text: .ssm_object output ssm_profiles() ssm_measures(). amax positive real number corresponding radius circle. used scale amplitude values determine amplitude labels drawn. legend_font_size positive real number corresponding size (pt) text labels legend (default = 12). scale_font_size positive real number corresponding size (pt) text labels amplitude displacement scales (default = 12). lowfit logical determining whether profiles low model fit (<.70) plotted, dashed borders (default = TRUE). repel experimental argument plotting text labels instead colors. angle_labels character vector specifying text labels plot around circle scale. Can also specify NULL default numerical angle labels vector empty strings ("") hide labels. NULL, must length ordering angles argument ssm_analyze(). (default = NULL) legend.box.spacing double corresponding distance (inches) add data plot legend (default = 0). palette string corresponding palette used ColorBrewer color fill aesthetics. set NULL, points appear blue legend (useful showing coverage high number variables). ... Currently ignored.

title: Create a Circular Plot of SSM Results — ssm_plot_circle

what: Standardize circumplex scales using normative data — standardize
title: Standardize circumplex scales using normative data — standardize
text: Take data frame containing circumplex scales, angle definitions scale, normative data (package custom) return data frame specified circumplex scale transformed standard scores (.e., z-scores) based comparison normative data.

title: Standardize circumplex scales using normative data — standardize
code: standardize(   .data,   scales,   angles,   instrument,   sample = 1,   prefix = "",   suffix = "_z" )

title: Standardize circumplex scales using normative data — standardize
text: .data Required. data frame containing least circumplex scales. scales Required. variable names column numbers variables .data contain circumplex scales standardized. angles Required. numeric vector containing angular displacement circumplex scale included scales (degrees). instrument Required. instrument object package. see available circumplex instruments, see instruments(). sample Required. integer corresponding normative sample use standardizing scale scores (default = 1). See ?norms see normative samples available instrument. prefix Optional. string include beginning newly calculated scale variables' names, scale name suffix (default = ""). suffix Optional. string include end newly calculated scale variables' names, scale name prefix (default = "_z").

title: Standardize circumplex scales using normative data — standardize

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way.   enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions).   simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[.   Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround.   Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually :   Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }
